channel.title: ASF JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [COMPRESS-707] TAR: TarUtils.verifyCheckSum() throws an Exception when checksum could not be parsed
item.description:
When parsing a TAR entry, the checksum is read from the header and verified.

 

final long storedSum = parseOctal(header, TarConstants.CHKSUM_OFFSET, TarConstants.CHKSUMLEN);

When the checksum itself is invalid (e.g. the octal number could not be parsed), an exception is thrown by the method TarUtils.parseOctal :

java.lang.IllegalArgumentException: Invalid byte 0 at offset 4 in '4712{NUL}36{NUL}' len=8

This exception is non-descriptive, and in our opinion TarUtils.verifyCheckSum should just return false when the checksum could not be parsed.

We will open a pull request on GitHub to address this. We will include an altered version of the bla.tar test file to cover this edge case.
item.summary: TAR: TarUtils.verifyCheckSum() throws an Exception when checksum could not be parsed

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.

comments.comment:
rdvdijk

Why should the code ignore a checksum? This sounds like a CVE waiting to happen.

How would you expect to detect corrupt or malicious files?

In the meantime, I've added a small amount of context to the exception message. The full "story" is the stack trace, which you may not show your users, but shows that the problem is a checksum issue.

See git master and/or snapshot builds in https://repository.apache.org/content/repositories/snapshots/

HTH

Thanks for you feedback.

We have encountered a TAR file "in the wild" that can be opened just fine with the tar command, or by double-clicking it in Ubuntu and opening it in a GUI.

However, commons-compress fails with the above-mentioned exception.

It turns out that the manipulated test-file that we added in the pull request cannot be extracted at all using the tar command. The file can be unarchived using our fork.

We will do some further analysis and supply a similar TAR file once we can create one like it.

rdvdijk

OK, let us know when you have something reproducible. TY!

ggregory 

We've created a TAR file that exactly recreates the problem that we encountered. See attached COMPRESS-707.tar.

The cause is that the checksum field is not terminated by a 'space' and a 'NUL', but is terminated directly by a 'NUL' after the checksum. As if it was a null-terminated string. The command line tar command correctly extracts this file without any warnings. Commons-compress throws the aforementioned exception.

Now that we've a better understanding of this problem, we would like to propose to fix this in the parseOctal method, and allow values to be terminated by a NUL byte. Would you agree, or would you propose another solution? If you agree, we can create a pull request for it.

Did some more digging, to check how TAR parses the checksum field. We found this:

https://github.com/Distrotech/tar/blob/273975bec1ff7d591d7ab8a63c08a02a285ffad3/src/list.c#L723-L730

      for (;;)
    {
      value += *where++ - '0';
      if (where == lim || ! ISODIGIT (*where))
        break;
      overflow |= value ^ (value << LG_8 >> LG_8);
      value <<= LG_8;
    }

This code parses the checksum left-to-right (start-to-end?) and breaks when the first non-"ISODIGIT" is found. In our edge case, this would mean that parsing stops at the first NUL byte.

The commons-compress code currently determines the start and end offsets by trimming all spaces and NUL bytes. It does not account for NUL bytes "in the middle" of the checksum.

Hello rdvdijk
I'll take a look. Please post your stack trace.

ON macOS, if I run:

tar -t -v COMPRESS-707.tar

then tar just hangs. I left it running for 2 minutes.
tar --help says:

...
bsdtar 3.5.3 - libarchive 3.7.4 zlib/1.2.12 liblzma/5.4.3 bz2lib/1.0.8

On Linux, if I run:

$ tar tvf COMPRESS-707.tar 
-rw-rw-rw- 0/0              16 1970-01-01 01:00 hi-gary.txt

This completes instantly.

$ tar --version
tar (GNU tar) 1.30
Copyright (C) 2017 Free Software Foundation, Inc.
License GPLv3+: GNU GPL version 3 or later <https://gnu.org/licenses/gpl.html>.
This is free software: you are free to change and redistribute it.
There is NO WARRANTY, to the extent permitted by law.Written by John Gilmore and Jay Fenlason.

Here is the stack trace you asked for:

org.apache.commons.compress.archivers.ArchiveException: Corrupted TAR archive.    at org.apache.commons.compress.archivers.tar.TarArchiveEntry.parseTarHeader(TarArchiveEntry.java:1468)
    at org.apache.commons.compress.archivers.tar.TarArchiveEntry.<init>(TarArchiveEntry.java:527)
    at org.apache.commons.compress.archivers.tar.TarArchiveInputStream.getNextEntry(TarArchiveInputStream.java:431)
    at org.apache.commons.compress.archivers.TarTest.testCompress707(TarTest.java:499)
    at java.base/java.lang.reflect.Method.invoke(Method.java:580)
    at java.base/java.util.ArrayList.forEach(ArrayList.java:1596)
    at java.base/java.util.ArrayList.forEach(ArrayList.java:1596)
Caused by: java.lang.IllegalArgumentException: verifyCheckSum(): Invalid byte 0 at offset 4 in '4324{NUL}36{NUL}' len=8
    at org.apache.commons.compress.archivers.tar.TarUtils.parseOctal(TarUtils.java:579)
    at org.apache.commons.compress.archivers.tar.TarUtils.verifyCheckSum(TarUtils.java:945)
    at org.apache.commons.compress.archivers.tar.TarArchiveEntry.parseTarHeaderBlock(TarArchiveEntry.java:1501)
    at org.apache.commons.compress.archivers.tar.TarArchiveEntry.parseUstarHeaderBlock(TarArchiveEntry.java:1532)
    at org.apache.commons.compress.archivers.tar.TarArchiveEntry.parseTarHeader(TarArchiveEntry.java:1466)
    ... 6 more

I understand the exception. However, GNU-tar does not trip up on this, and bsdtar clearly does (bsdtar: see new comment below).

The question is, what should commons-compress do in this case?

Regarding your test on Mac OS: I think the -f flag is missing, or else the default path /dev/st0 is used, i.e.:

$ bsdtar --version
bsdtar 3.4.0 - libarchive 3.4.0 zlib/1.2.11 liblzma/5.2.4 bz2lib/1.0.8 liblz4/1.9.2 libzstd/1.4.4

$ bsdtar -t -v -f COMPRESS-707.tar 
-rw-rw-rw-  0 0      0          16 Jan  1  1970 hi-gary.txt

Running this on Linux works for me.

The bsdtar from Debian 12 also completes successfully:

$ bsdtar --version
bsdtar 3.6.2 - libarchive 3.6.2 zlib/1.2.13 liblzma/5.4.1 bz2lib/1.0.8 liblz4/1.9.4 libzstd/1.5.4

Gary, your version number doesn't really make sense bsdtar is part of the libarchive distribution, so the versions should match even in the Apple fork. Maybe you have a dependency problem?
Yep, I forgot the "-f"! Sorry about that!

rdvdijk 

This is now addressed in git master and snapshot builds in https://repository.apache.org/content/repositories/snapshots/ with the existing "lenient" flag now encompassing its effect to parsing checksums.

In this specific case, which doesn't strictly match the TAR spec, the checksum is 4 bytes followed by a NUL, and matches the checksum computation on the header such that org.apache.commons.compress.archivers.tar.TarArchiveEntry.isCheckSumOK() returns true.

To enable leniency, use a constructor that specifies "lenent" or the Builder.

For example:

      TarArchiveInputStream s = TarArchiveInputStream.builder()
        .setPath(path)
        .setLenient(true)
        ...
        .get();}

ggregory 

Thanks for fixing this, we're eagerly awaiting the next release with this in it.

Hello rdvdijk 

We are working toward a release but it might be a week or two before a release candidate.
